text:
What is lettering and how to make money on it
01 Nov 2019 by Svetlana Kurako
Drawing letters can become not only an interesting creative hobby, but also a source of income.



Svetlana KurakoMarketologist, business development expert, letterer.
The word "lettering" is new to many, but we constantly encounter what it means. A beautiful label, an original sign in a store, a menu written on a blackboard with an interesting font are all examples of lettering. Do not forget about greeting cards, prints on T-shirts, logos ... Lettering surrounds us everywhere. And you can learn to create interesting compositions of letters on your own. We tell you where to start a beginner and how to achieve success in this type of creativity.
What is lettering
Lettering is called drawing beautiful letters, and in this sense it can be compared with calligraphy. Indeed, both there and there the goal is to get the original lettering that would be distinguished by originality and originality, reflecting a special mood. However, in lettering, the emphasis is still on drawing, it is closer to fine art than to writing.







Author works

For a long time, "drawing letters" was just one of the many creative directions. But in the XXI century it rapidly developed into an independent, demanded and very well-paid type of activity. And you can be sure that this trend will not pass lightning fast. As long as there is a need for the original execution of the text, letters will also be needed, that is, specialists in working with letters.
Where to begin
Most believe that it makes no sense to undertake drawing letters if it is not possible to devote at least a few hours a day to this activity. This is actually not the case. The main thing is to do it regularly, even if it is 5 minutes a day. Such activities will bring more benefits than an hour once a week.
A distinctive feature of lettering is that it does not need to have a basic art education. Initial drawing skills and 5‚Äì30 minutes of time daily will be quite enough.
Of course, business will bring success faster if you do not have to independently learn the basics and fill up the bumps. Therefore, those who already know how to draw benefit, have an idea of composition, perspective, color combinations and so on. But it‚Äôs quite possible to learn all this, so the lack of professional artistic skills should not stop you.
Lettering is an ideal activity for beginners, and here's why:

It is much easier to make progress in it than in any other form of creativity.
It does not require sophisticated skills, because in order to make beautiful compositions from letters, you do not need to be able to sculpt a plaster head or draw a cheetah in a jump.
There are clear rules for writing alphabetic compositions, and for the commercial success of your work, just stick to them.
After a month of regular exercises, you can notice a noticeable increase in skill.

For these reasons, one can succeed in lettering without having a creative education. There are several letter-tellers whose names are known throughout the world, such as Stefan Kunz and Lauren Hom. They acquired their skills on their own, and their example is the best motivation for those who doubt themselves and their abilities.
Where and how to study
It is best to start with words - this will allow you to "get your hand", to master the basic techniques and moves. Then connect your imagination, study the work of other authors (for example, on Behance) and experiment!
Children's copy-books for training will not work, because letter-writing harmonious from the point of view of lettering often differs from what we were taught at school. In lettering, each letter should look compositionally attractive, so you should pay attention to the special recipe for modern lettering, which can be found on the Internet.


Author's work

If the lesson captivates you and you understand that you want to master it, it makes sense to sign up for online courses. Most beginner letterwriters need to be evaluated from the outside, since it is very difficult to notice the shortcomings of your work yourself. And in the learning process, you will not only get acquainted with new techniques, but also learn to see errors and correct them.
Of great importance is a sense of style and personal taste. They will come only with experience, so regularly train and focus on the masters whose work is original, interesting and, most importantly, in demand.
What tools are needed
The choice of tools and materials largely depends on what goals you set. For example, to draw letters for personal needs (for example, to arrange cards for friends), it makes no sense to spend money on expensive professional tools. And if you plan to create high-quality projects for commercial purposes, then, of course, you need to invest in the best materials.
On the other hand, if you try to draw with high-quality pencils or brushes at least once, you will immediately feel the difference. Working with good materials is much more pleasant and comfortable, and the result immediately becomes much better.


Author's work

The minimum set that you need to start drawing for yourself:

Soft simple pencil. It is best to take 2B, but if you like to press while drawing, you can limit yourself to HB or B (bold lines are harder to erase, they leave a mark on paper.
Eraser. It is desirable that it is soft so that it cleans the pencil well and does not smear it.
Paper - you can take a regular office, for drawing or buy an album for drawing.
Colored markers, pencils or pens. Needed to draw contours and paint over.

A professional set is useful for those who want to create a competitive design or draw letters at a high level. It includes:

Soft pencil. Again, for those who do not like to push hard, 2B is suitable, and if you draw with pressure, it is better to take a harder one.
Eraser. It is important that it is very soft and leaves no residue. Many illustrators use a gag eraser that does not scratch the paper, and the work as a result looks neat and presentable.
Liners. Needed to draw contours. For lovers of thick lines, 0.8, 1.0 and 1.2 are suitable, thinner liners are marked 0.2, 0.3, 0.5. There are no universal recommendations for liners: choose those with which you are comfortable working.
Two-tip brushpen. This is a tool with a marker on one end and a brush on the other. You can make a contour with a marker or paint over the letters, and the second tip is perfect for those who learn brush lettering, that is, drawing letters with a brush.
Brushpen with one brush tip. This tool is more difficult to master than the previous one, it is more difficult to control writing with it, it requires higher skill and therefore is not suitable for beginners. However, it is he who is needed if you want to create letters that are fashionable today, in which there are very thick and thin lines.
Paper. Its density should be at least 80 g / m¬≤, that is, ordinary office sheets for the printer are suitable.

This list of tools is not universal. Each letterer eventually understands what it is more convenient for him to work with, and collects his own set of favorite instruments. However, to start it is better to use this list.
How to make money on lettering
The success of lettering is determined by the commercial benefit it brings. Oddly enough, but beauty is far from the main thing for successful sales. It is necessary that the work be in demand, and for this it is important to create primarily trending things.
The main principles of successful lettering:

brevity of the composition;
minimalism;
following trends.

If the first two are gained with experience, the second is the result of a close study of the market, the work of popular letterters, as well as an analysis of the sold and sought-after compositions.
For successful sales, it is very important to know at least some principles of the functioning of this market. Many letterwriters were successful only because their first specialty was related to economics, advertising, or sales. Using their knowledge, they were able to correctly express themselves and attract customers.







Author works

You can sell works in two fundamentally different ways:

through social networks or your own site;
on microstock - platforms where anyone wants to sell their creative work for sale.

Each of them has its own advantages and disadvantages. Let's consider them in detail.
How to sell work through social networks or your site
This option requires active promotion.

Define your target audience. To do this, set the area in which you will create: for example, creating inscriptions for T-shirts and greeting cards or working on brand logos.
Create a unique selling proposition - something that will distinguish you from your competitors.
Work on the image. Collaborate with other bloggers, participate in thematic events or start a master class.
Create a portfolio and regularly replenish it. Potential customers should know what you can do.

Benefits

You work with clients directly, and it‚Äôs convenient: you don‚Äôt have to predict the wishes of the abstract potential buyer, your customer himself will tell you exactly what he wants.
Properly configured advertising in social networks can bring you widespread fame, especially if you post it on popular blogs and correctly identify your target audience.

disadvantages

Promotion of a blog on social networks requires active participation and material investments, this is not passive income.
Almost always, success depends on the external appeal of the blog, your activity and advertising - without this, you cannot attract a customer.

How to sell through microstock
Microstock is a universal base for the sale of products of your creativity, as they are represented by masters with a name, and novice letterters. These sites do not impose high requirements on the level of performance, so even beginners can successfully earn money on their compositions.

Register on one or more sites (Shutterstock, Adobe Stock, Depositphotos and others), familiarize yourselfcomply with the rules of the placement of works (resolution, quality, requirements for the design of the profile).
Download work and wait for buyers.

Benefits

This is a relatively passive income: each work can be sold as many times as they want to buy, so theoretically the income from it is unlimited.
Microstock does not require your constant presence, advertising and so on.
This type of business does without material investments.

disadvantages

At first, profits grow very slowly.
There is high competition on microstock, so you need to constantly improve and monitor trends.
Work involves a flexible schedule, which means that you will need a good self-organization. It is necessary to regularly replenish the portfolio, master new directions, develop your own style that will attract buyers.


Ideally, it is good to combine both methods of monetization: their advantages and disadvantages mutually cancel each other and allow you to establish stable regular sales. By concentrating on one thing, you are missing out on the opportunities that another option provides.
In any case, get ready for the fact that there will be no instant result. Perhaps in the first months, profits from microstock will be minimal, and social networks will require investments in promotion. Be patient. When it works, you will see how profitable it is.
Conclusion
New trends are always attractive and convenient for monetization. Lettering, despite its novelty, has a huge advantage: it will not lose its relevance over the years, which means it makes sense to invest time and effort in its development.
